utterances: Makes no damn sense - no damn sense at all - to make those available.
President Trump tweeted yesterday, quote, ""I am looking into 3D plastic guns being sold to the public.
Already spoke to NRA.
Doesn't seem to make much sense,"" exclamation point.
Matt Largey is with member station KUT and has covered this issue for a while.
Matt, thanks for being here.
You're welcome.
So we've got President Trump saying, hey; it doesn't make sense to have blueprints online for these weapons.
At the same time, it's his State Department that settled a case just weeks ago that essentially opened the door to their release.
So can you explain what's going on here?
Yeah.
That's right.
So previously, the Obama administration had taken the stance that these files should not be released, and that continued for a while under the Trump administration.

But, yeah, then in April, there was kind of this surprise settlement between the State Department and Defense Distributed, the company that's distributing these online plans, and the State Department agreed to kind of carve out an exception for the company.
Huh.
But as you note - I mean, it was the Obama administration that stopped this company from releasing all these plans.
But before 2013, they had already done so, and as we all know, things that are on the Internet never actually disappear.
So if they are essentially already available online, does this ruling by this judge yesterday really mean anything?

Well, it's hard to tell because, yeah, in 2013, Cody Wilson, the guy who founded Defense Distributed - he posted the plans for this single-shot 3D-printed pistol on the Internet, and it's been online kind of ever since.
Like, he hasn't been distributing it, but those files have been available on file-sharing sites.
They've been passed around by people.
They - that file's existed.

What's new here is that he released a whole bunch of other plans for different guns, and those have also been downloaded thousands of times because they were online from Friday night until just last night.
What do you know about Cody Wilson?
Well, he characterizes himself as kind of an anarchist, a libertarian.
He's very much into gun rights.
He told me that this all started for him after the cablegate (ph) thing with Julian Assange and releasing all those diplomatic cables.
And he kind of thought about, what might WikiLeaks for guns look like?
And so that kind of started him on this journey.
So what happens now, I mean, legally speaking, with the judge now saying, we need to time out in order to decide where to go?
How does the case move forward?
Well, I would imagine that Defense Distributed will probably appeal this ruling from the judge.
But the merits of the case haven't actually been heard yet, so the actual questions at issue here haven't been decided, and, in fact, they've never been decided.
This has been winding its way through the courts for a few years now, but a judge has never actually ruled on whether or not this is legal.
KUT's Matt Largey.
Thanks so much, Matt.
You're quite welcome.
Continuing on the theme of same sex marriage, let's turn to the black church.

Others turn to scriptures on judgment and say that judgment is God's not theirs to make.
On the phone from Atlanta, Georgia is Dr. Robert Franklin, professor of social ethics at Emory University.
Dr. Franklin, thank you for joining us.
Thank you for having me.
I'm standing in front of one of the classic views in Egypt - the pyramid of Khafre, in front of it, the Sphinx, and yet there's not a tourist to be seen anywhere.
The entrance to the park is shuttered and closed.
(Soundbite of gate)
A watchman padlocks the main gate to the pyramids after letting a utility vehicle out.
This is the beginning of the high season for tourism, but all the people who work in the industry are standing around, carrying trinkets with no one to sell to.
Nearby, those who hire out camels and horses are also suffering.
The camels are bedecked with colorful saddles, waiting for paying customers that won't be arriving anytime soon.
The uprising here sparked a massive exodus of tourists, and the loss of revenue could run into billions of dollars.
In Giza, camel owner Abdul Mohammed says after two weeks with no income, people can't afford to feed their animals.
He says several animals have been left to starve.
Like, now, 14 days, people not work because this problem.
These people, they love the tourists, you know.
'Cause if you have a tourist, everybody happy.
You work, you have money, you have food, you have everything.
Twenty-one-year-old Amir also makes his living by giving horseback rides to tourists.
He was one of the now-famous riders that led a charge on the protesters in Tahrir Square last week.
(Speaking foreign language)
Speaking to NPR, Amir, who has a cut down the side of his face and a bandaged head, said despite what people alleged, he wasn't paid by the government to be there.
(Speaking foreign language)
Amir says he just wanted to draw attention to the plight of the tourism sector and was suddenly embroiled in the fight taking place on the square.
He says he lost his horse in the charge.
(Speaking foreign language)
He says it makes him very sad when he sees footage of the battle.
Amir doesn't want that image of violence broadcast to the world, he says, because it will scare off tourists.
Not all the pyramid workers are against the protest movement.
Perfume seller Mohammed Hassan says people are afraid to speak openly for fear of reprisals from the state security services.
He says there is a lot of confusion about what's going on.
In the morning you say this man is good, at night you say this man is bad.
Because you heard many things - many things you doesn't know it - and also you are not sure if it's right or not.
I don't know who's right, who's wrong.
But my feeling, we hope that the work that's come again, the tourists come again because we live from the tourists.
And then he quickly tries to sell us a hundred-dollar bottle of perfume.
(Soundbite of hotel)
Across Cairo, hotels are empty.
At one nearby hotel, the management is taking advantage of the lull to make repairs.
Though no one would speak to us on the record, the manager acknowledged that there was no one to be bothered by the construction noise, as almost everyone has left.
Almost everyone - but not this 24-year-old German tourist who refers to himself as ""Billy Six"" or ""Travel Billy."" He says he knew there was an uprising but decided to come anyway.
He's walking across Africa.
I mean, there's trouble nearly everywhere in Africa.
So it's not a new thing here.
He says he's been mistaken for a journalist.
He complains...
They even took the camera away and it was not easy to get it back.
Billy Six from Berlin says he's been through some rough times over the past week.
They arrested me sometimes, talking and asking a lot of questions.
Many funny people who were very, very, important but they let me out and everything is OK.
Hakuna Matata.
He says he's off to Alexandria next, undeterred by the continuing unrest.
Lourdes Garcia-Navarro, NPR News, Cairo.
Compared to the rest of the Arab world, Morocco has relatively free media.
But the two state-run TV stations still operate under tight restrictions.
So these days, Moroccans are bypassing mainstream media to post and share videos online.
And younger Moroccans say they now turn to YouTube and other social-networking sites for news that the authorities don't want them to see.
NPR's Peter Kenyon reports from Ifrane, Morocco.
But Moroccans didn't see those tense scenes on the evening news.
Instead, they watched raw, amateur video clips on sites such as YouTube and Dailymotion.
(SOUNDBITE OF PROTEST)

In the Arabic-language paper Al Massa, journalist Sanna Talbot(ph) wrote that the two state-run channels had been dealt a knockout blow by Web sites that make potential correspondents out of every Moroccan with a cell-phone camera.
Talbot says young people in particular are finding that the Internet offers a way for controversial news and images to escape the filter of the state-controlled media.
Yes.

They are getting their news from YouTube or Dailymotion more and more, especially when it concerns some event that national channels are not very concerning to show the true image about what happened.
One reason the government has made only occasional efforts to block Web sites may be that they're still used by only a minority of Moroccans.
Professor Mohammed Ibrahim is an expert on new media at Al Akhawayn University in the Atlas Mountain town of Ifrane near Fes.
Compared to other Arab countries, Morocco is very well positioned.
But so far right now, I think that the political impact of bloggers or YouTube will remain limited.
Al Akhawayn is a modern, Western-style campus that is completely wired.
Moroccan students here say they use the Internet every day, often for socializing or for research projects, but sometimes for news.
These do not appear to be young radicals.
They're cautious about the veracity of much of what pops up on the Internet, and they don't necessarily object to some government control on television news.
But 19-year-old international studies major Sara al-Mamouhi(ph) says she likes having the option to see uncensored news on the Web.
Internet, I would say, is the main source for information of what's going on around the world.
